Award.AwardTitle: NRI: Small: Collaborative Research: Rethinking Motion Generation for Robots Operating in Human Workspaces

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: This proposal develops a new motion planning paradigm for enabling robots to work in the presence of humans or cooperatively with humans as co-workers. The paradigm is intended to be fast, reactive, and responsive to the requirements that arise from human-robot interaction. It involves the definition and subsequent implementation of constraints that encode properties of human-aware paths and can be translated to cost functions characterizing path quality. New motion planners are proposed. The operation of these planners is guided by constraints and their corresponding cost functions. The planners produce paths compatible with a given set of constraints. A mechanism to incorporate user feedback on the relative importance of constraints is provided and semi-autonomous operation of the robots is considered. Importantly, the planners are embedded in a novel hybrid-systems framework that allows a robot to automatically switch among planners, and hence behaviors, in order to take into account different constraints and user preferences that arise in the context of semi-autonomous operation. Besides the actual implementation of the planners on specific platforms, this project also disseminates all developed libraries and planners. Compatibility will the Robot Operating System (ROS) is provided for wide adoption, while tutorials at major conferences are planned. The training of graduate students and female undergraduate students are a central focus of this proposal.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This proposal focused on the development of motion generation procedures that can be combined to generate varying levels of autonomy for robot co-workers. These procedures allow in general the computation of paths that satisfy hard constraints and optimize soft constraints that capture the quality of the path. Our planners can be integrated in a sense, plan and act loop in real and simulated systems. Our goal in this project was to develop both the theoretical foundations and the practical implementation of our motion planning work. We achieved both.

Through this project we have developed new algorithms for (1) planning with general geometric constraints,  (2) planning that tends to minimize workspace displacement, (2) time-optimal trajectory generation, (3) planning that combines sampling-based and optimization based approaches and (4) a new approach to combine path planning with trajectory optimization. The developed planners all operate in a framework that allows reasoning or their properties and their asymptotic convergence.

Some of our planners were motivated by our collaboration with the Robonaut2 team at NASA’s Johnson Space Center. This robot is designed to operate on board the International Space Station (ISS) in zero gravity and should eventually take over of the menial tasks currently performed by astronauts, thereby allowing astronauts to focus more on their scientific mission. The included figure shows several snapshots of Robonaut2 as it is climbing across handrails of a module of the ISS. Computing such motions is challenging: each step requires coordinated motions of 15 joints (7 in each leg and one rotating waist joint). The motions are further constrained by a requirement to keep the torso upright (needed for experimental validation on earth) and by the very limited maneuvering space inside the ISS (the robot cannot stand straight up, for instance).

All our work is integrated in the Open Motion Planning (OMPL) library. OMPL has been significantly enhanced with the project as it is outlined in the original proposal. OMPL currently has more than 1,600 registered users and an active message board. This project has trained several post graduate, graduate and undergraduate students. OMPL was used in the undergraduate and graduate class offered at Rice University.
